quoteLast: by the ship's clock the _Adventurer_ gave a prolonged screech and, moorings cast off, edged her way out of the basin and dipped her nose in the laughing waters of the bay, embarked at last on a voyage that was destined to fully vindicate her new name.
title: The Adventure Club Afloat
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Caswell, Edward C., 1879-1963 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , your ladyship." quoteLast: --that means Russell had plenty of time to kill the girl after the rain stopped and to get out on the road and slip on to that running board. And the car slowed up, where he rolled off the running board, at eighteen minutes past eleven.

quoteFirst: Lady Jersey," announced an attendant, "the Duke of Wellington is at the door, and desires to be admitted." "What o'clock is it?" she asked. "
quoteLast: , your Ladyship." He cannot be admitted.

quoteTime: seven minutes past eleven A. M.
quoteLast: ; that of St. Louis, five minutes of eleven A. M.; that in San Francisco, fifteen minutes before nine A. M.

quoteFirst: Towards noon it began to cloud up, and we had some rain, and I had strong hopes that we should have a cloudy, dark night. The moon would not rise until
quoteLast: , and if we could be aided by a few clouds we should have sufficient darkness; for be it known that in these tropical climates, where almost every star is a moon, there is no such thing as darkness when the firmament is clear. But my hopes began to fade, with the day, for one cloud disappeared after another, as the sun went down, until the night promised to be as serene and bright as the last.
title:
The Cruise of the Alabama and the Sumter
From the Private Journals and Other Papers of Commander R. Semmes, C.S.N., and Other Officers
author: Semmes, Raphael, 1809-1877
